comments.commentBody: A recent article in Mother Jones makes an important point: Democrats need to stop mocking other Americans for being concerned about homeland security.  It is a losing posture. Democrats, including Obama, need to at least fake caring about national security, or they will lose the White House. Once they win, they can stop faking, and neglect America's security needs all they want.

It's not that Americans don't have empathy, it's because the people are not fools. FYI: the United States government has admitted that no vetting procedure is in place that absolutely guarantees that Syrian refugees are "safe". (Google it.)

According to Uncle Sam, the "rigorous vetting" that you believe in is, unfortunately, sub par at this point in time. And that's why so many governors don't want to cooperate with Obama.

And while I honor your free speech, I believe that your argument has no merit since you've ignored this proven fact.
Or - if someone can pass that level of screening - why not just buy a plane ticket and come on a tourist visa?

For some reason, we tend to think of terrorists as superhuman.  In order to pass the already stringent screening process and outfox our intelligence professionals, potential jihadists would have to be extraordinarily sophisticated well-trained, and patient enough to wait 18-24 months.  After all that, if there was even a hint of suspicion, the refugee would not be admitted.  Wouldn't ISIS be much more likely to try to turn someone already living here, or sneak a jihadist in over the border?

It's not surprising that 36 percent of people surveyed in the Bronx said there have been times in the past year when they lacked money to pay for enough food for their family. A recent Times article mentioned a family where the breadwinner had been working at a Subway sandwich shop. The family had been paying $1500 a month in rent. Even with a second, similarly sized income, $1500 a month rent for a family like this is frightening to contemplate. They still have to pay gas and electric. It's hard to imagine how they could afford phone or internet service. Add more than $100 per 30 days for each working adult for a Metro Card. Even if you could buy all your clothes, including shoes and winter coats, at a Goodwill store, there would be precious little left to feed a family of four.

As someone who hasn't lived in New York in four decades, and never expects to be able to afford to again, I'm not surprised. And it isn't any secret what the problem is.

New York has always had wealthy -- superwealthy -- citizens. But I don't recall that they used to regard the place as their private preserve, and operate with such utter contempt for anyone who not only wasn't one of them but had no particular desire to be one of them. I don't recall such *obliviousness* to the rest of life. It's a very serious problem. If ordinary professionals, let alone ordinary people without fancy educations, can't get by while working, what kind of hell and uprooting await them in old age? How can there be art if artists only visit? The entire notion of "citizen" seems to be gone, a bad situation for an American city-state, and what's nearly as bad is that the wealthy don't seem to understand that they aren't interesting enough to sustain a culture on their own.

I'm skeptical that oilprice is right about coal in SE Asia, looking 5 - 10 years out, but we'll see. And I am not assuming that solar is what will automatically prevent that rise.

I think the awareness of the health costs of uncontrolled (or poorly controlled) coal-fired plants will shut-off the majority of growth of coal-fired plants, and start retiring the oldest/dirtiest. Socially India and SE Asia compete with China, and often take cues from it. China is starting to wind down coal, and the social sentiment against it in China is now very high. It's seen as obsolete, dirty, corrupt, and a blight on life ... and all of these things are true in China.

Modi-ism economically is old-school, like Mao. It's going the way of Harper, Abbott ...
From oilprice.com coal use is going to rise in India and Southeast Asia. Solar is a minor player there.

It was the same in 1964 when my family packed up and left for Florida.
We were 9 people living in a four room shot gun apartment in Bushwick in Brooklyn. The rent was $50.45 per month but the landlord wanted $2.00 more illegally.
I moved back temporarily for six months in 1970 until I joined the Navy, When I returned in 1975 I saw no reason to stay. Everyone seemed to be surviving on scams. Selling cigarettes from their basement, washing cars, selling stuff from hijacked trucks or selling food prepared in their unlicensed ( and uninspected )kitchens.
I headed back South and never looked back. Financially I was much better off and still am. There are few people hustling stolen goods because there are a lot of people with religion and integrity here who won't deal that way. Someone keeps moving here, we have 12,000 apartments being built or built on the schedule. And companies from the North keep moving in. I don't see how life in NYC and the rest of the Northeast can ever get any better for working people.
